Question Text: Which of the following properties are characteristics of virtual networks (but not necessarily characteristics of SDN). Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Separates the data and control plane.
b. Refactors network control so that network behavior is controlled from a single logically centralized controller.
c. Separates logical and physical networks.
d. Often deployed in data center networks to allow multiple tenants to share physical network infrastructure.
e. Abstracts the details of the physical network.
LLM Explanation: Virtual networks have the following key characteristics:  c) They separate the logical network topology from the underlying physical network infrastructure. Multiple virtual networks can be overlaid on the same physical network.  d) They are commonly used in multi-tenant data center environments to allow different tenants (customers) to share the same physical network hardware while maintaining isolation between their networks.  e) The physical network details are abstracted and hidden from the virtual networks built on top. The virtual network operates independently of the specifics of the underlying physical network.  While virtual networks and SDN are related concepts that are often used together, properties (a) separating data and control planes, and (b) logically centralized control, are more specific to SDN rather than virtual networks in general.

Question Text: Which of the following are possible ways of creating virtual links in a virtual network? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an IP packet is encapsulated in an MPLS tunnel by attaching an MPLS header to the packet.
b. Longest-prefix match forwarding on an IP router.
c. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an Ethernet packet sent between two virtual machines is encapsulated in an IP packet.
d. VLAN switching based on a VLAN tag.
e. Pairs of virtual Ethernet interfaces, where one end of the Ethernet interface pair resides in the virtual environment, and the other resides in the root namespace on the host machine.
LLM Explanation: Virtual links in a virtual network can be created through various methods. Wide-area tunnels using MPLS (a) or IP encapsulation of Ethernet packets (c) enable virtual links across networks. VLAN switching based on tags (d) allows logical separation and virtual linking of network segments. Virtual Ethernet interface pairs (e) can connect virtual environments to host machines. Longest-prefix match forwarding (b) is a regular IP routing mechanism and not specifically used for creating virtual links.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'Network Virtualization by Victor Moreno and Kumar Reddy', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following are true of the Mininet network emulator? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. It requires running OpenFlow-capable switches.
b. It is difficult to use it to route traffic for real services.
c. Mininet only allows users to create three types of topologies: linear, tree, and single-switch topologies.
d. It can create an emulation that runs across multiple physically distributed nodes.
e. All of the hosts in the topology must run the same underlying operating system.
LLM Explanation: Mininet is a network emulator that runs a collection of end-hosts, switches, routers, and links on a single Linux kernel. It does not require running OpenFlow-capable switches (a) as it can emulate them. While it is easy to create various network topologies in Mininet, it is not limited to just linear, tree, and single-switch topologies (c). Mininet can create an emulation that runs across multiple physically distributed nodes (d). However, it is difficult to use Mininet to route traffic for real services (b) as it is primarily designed for testing and research purposes. Lastly, the hosts in a Mininet topology do not all have to run the same underlying operating system (e).

Question Text: What are the benefits of emulation as opposed to, say, simulation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. An emulation will complete faster than a simulation.
b. An emulator makes it possible to "port" experiments from one machine to another.
c. An emulator allows the experimenter run real software on each of the nodes in the emulation.
d. An emulation is easier to debug than a simulation.
e. Every run of the emulator will yield exactly the same results, resulting in reproducible experiments.
LLM Explanation: The benefits of emulation over simulation are:b) An emulator makes it possible to 'port' experiments from one machine to another. The emulation environment can be packaged and moved to different hardware, allowing experiments to be reproduced on other machines.  c) An emulator allows the experimenter to run real software on each of the nodes in the emulation. Unlike a simulation which models software behavior, an emulator provides a realistic environment where actual software can be run on emulated hardware.The other options are not necessarily benefits of emulation:a) An emulation may not necessarily complete faster than a simulation, it depends on the complexity. d) An emulation is not necessarily easier to debug than a simulation.e) Emulator runs are not guaranteed to yield exactly the same results each time, as there can still be some variability.

Question Text: Which of the following are possible in Mininet? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Measuring the latency between a host in San Francisco and a host in Los Angeles.
b. Assigning custom IP addresses to each node in the topology.
c. Assigning IP addresses to each node in the topology using a DHCP server.
d. Running performance measurement tools (e.g., iperf, wget) between nodes.
e. "Shaping" a link between two nodes to a particular traffic rate.
LLM Explanation: In Mininet, it is possible to assign custom IP addresses to each node in the topology (b), run performance measurement tools like iperf and wget between nodes (d), and shape the traffic rate on links between nodes (e). However, Mininet is an emulation environment running on a single machine, so it cannot measure actual latency between geographically distant hosts (a). Also, while IP addresses can be assigned, Mininet does not include a DHCP server for automatic IP assignment (c).

Question Text: Which of the following functions does FlowVisor enable? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different load balancing applications for all traffic between the same source-destination pair.
b. Allowing two controllers to control traffic on distinct VLANs.
c. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different Web load balancing applications for port 80 traffic.
d. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy control mechanisms for two distinct applications.
e. Allowing one controller to control TCP traffic and one controller to control UDP traffic.
LLM Explanation: FlowVisor enables network virtualization by allowing multiple controllers to simultaneously control overlapping sets of physical switches. It can slice the network based on various parameters like VLANs (b), distinct applications (d), or transport protocols like TCP/UDP (e). However, it cannot slice the network for the same type of traffic to different controllers, as in the case of options (a) and (c) where the same load balancing application or port 80 traffic would go to different controllers.

Question Text: Which of the following are stated applications of the Nicira Network Virtualization Platform? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Easier transition to IPv6 in data-center networks.
b. Creating more than 1024 virtual networks, as opposed to the alternative of using VLAN tags.
c. Allowing experimental protocols to coincide with a production network.
d. Central management of security policies.
e. Dynamic workload placement in multi-tenant data centers.
LLM Explanation: The Nicira Network Virtualization Platform enables several applications, including: b) creating more than 1024 virtual networks, which overcomes the limitation of VLANs; c) allowing experimental protocols to run alongside production traffic on the same physical network; d) centrally managing security policies across the virtual networks; and e) enabling dynamic workload placement for efficient resource utilization in multi-tenant data centers. While the platform likely makes IPv6 transition easier as well, this was not explicitly stated as an application in the course material.
URLs: ['Nicira Network Virtualization Platform Overview - Nicira Whitepaper', 'The Road to SDN: An Intellectual History of Programmable Networks - Feamster et al., ACM Queue 2013']

Question Text: Select the statement that is most true about the relationship between network virtualization and SDNs.
Choices:
a. Network virtualization is a potential enabler for software-defined networks, since the separation of data and control planes first requires the creation of a logical network.
b. Software-defined networking is a potential enabler for virtual networks, since separation of data and control planes makes it easier to manage a logical network topology.
c. Network virtualization is a new concept introduced by Amazon, Nicira, and industry players; it only made sense to talk about network virtualization once central SDN controllers existed.
d. Network virtualization and software-defined networking each enable the other: SDN cannot exist without network virtualization, and network virtualization cannot exist without SDN.
LLM Explanation: Both statements a and b are true about the relationship between network virtualization and SDNs. Network virtualization enables the creation of logical networks separate from the underlying physical infrastructure, which is a prerequisite for implementing SDNs that decouple the control and data planes. At the same time, SDN principles like the separation of control and data planes make it easier to manage and orchestrate virtual network topologies. So network virtualization and SDN are complementary technologies that enable and strengthen each other, but one is not strictly dependent on the other.
